Details: Two distinct test case approaches for DBT validation: Agent_1_Output provides comprehensive DBT query testing with full pytest infrastructure including fixtures and session management, while Agent_2_Output focuses specifically on SQL-to-DBT conversion validation with file-based testing. Both outputs are syntactically correct but serve different testing purposes with moderate semantic overlap.

Both outputs target DBT testing but with different scopes. Agent_1_Output focuses on general DBT query validation (total orders, spent calculations, performance, joins) while Agent_2_Output specifically targets SQL-to-DBT conversion validation (table references, syntax conversion, materialization). Overlap exists in DBT syntax compliance (TC009 vs TC001/TC010) and basic query structure validation, but core testing objectives diverge significantly.

Significant structural differences. Agent_1_Output uses comprehensive pytest architecture with fixtures (spark_session, test_data), session management, and structured test data creation. Agent_2_Output uses simple file-based testing with individual functions reading from files. Agent_1_Output has 9 test cases with placeholder implementations, Agent_2_Output has 10 test cases with complete implementations. Both follow pytest conventions but with fundamentally different approaches.

Syntactically correct pytest structure with proper fixtures and session management. Minor issues: test functions contain only 'pass' statements (lines 67-150), missing actual test implementations. SparkSession fixture properly configured with teardown. Test data fixture correctly structured with proper DataFrame creation.

Excellent syntax correctness with complete test implementations. All pytest functions properly defined with file reading and assertions. Minor issue: hardcoded file names (lines 8,18,28,etc.) may cause path issues in different environments. All assert statements properly structured and logical.

Both outputs demonstrate strong syntactic correctness. Agent_2_Output slightly superior due to complete implementations vs Agent_1_Output's placeholder functions. Both follow pytest best practices and Python syntax standards.

Complete test function implementations by replacing 'pass' statements with actual query logic and assertions. Add error handling for SparkSession failures. Consider adding more specific test data scenarios.
Replace hardcoded file paths with configurable parameters or fixtures. Add error handling for file reading operations. Consider adding setup/teardown for test file management.

Consider hybrid approach: combine Agent_1_Output's robust test infrastructure with Agent_2_Output's specific conversion validation focus. Both could benefit from integration testing scenarios and performance benchmarks.
